Accidentals
Accidentals can be set or changed by dragging an accidental symbol from the accidental palette to a note in the score.
If you only want to change the pitch of a note you can also select the note and:
UpIncrease the pitch of a note for one semitone.
DownDecrease the pitch of a note for one semitone.
Shift+UpIncrease the pitch of a note for one octave.
Shift+DownDecrease the pitch of a note for one Octave.
MuseScore automatically tries to set an appropriate accidental for the changed pitch. If you don't agree with this or you want to place an cautionary accidental (editorial accidental), then you have to manually drag an accidental from the accidental palette to the note. If you again change the pitch with cursor keys, this manual set accidental will be lost.
The menu function <Notes/Pitch spell> tries to guess the right accidentals for the whole score.

tr.td: Arpeggios are set by dragging an arpeggio symbol from the arpeggio palette to a note of a chord.
Barlines are changed by dragging a barline symbol from the barline palette to an barline in the score.

Beams are set automatically but the automatic setting can be manually overridden. For this drag a beam symbol from the beam palette to a note were you want to change the beam behaviour.
You can also first select a note and then double click the appropriate symbol in the beam palette.

museScoreManual.page:
Brackets
Remove
Select the bracket and press <Del>
Add
Drag a bracket symbol from the bracket palette to an empty space in the first measure of a system.
Change
Drag a bracket symbol from the bracket palette to an bracket in the score.
Edit
Double click on a bracket to enter edit mode, In edit mode you can drag the hight of a bracket to span arbitrary staves of a system.

tr.td:
Page breaks or line breaks (system breaks) can be enforced by dragging a page break symbol or line break symbol from the breaks palette to an empty space of a measure in the score.
The break will happen after the marked measure.
The visible break marks will not be printed of course.

museScoreManual.page:
Breath
To place a breath symbol drag it from the breath palette to a note in the score. The breath symbol will be placed before the note.

Chord Names Chord names can be entered by first selecting a note and then pressing <Ctrl+K>. This creates a chord name text object for the selected chord.
Type <space> to move to the next chord.
<Shift+Space> moves to the previous chord.
<Ctrl+Space> enters a <space> into the chord name text.
Chord names can be edited as normal text.

Clefs
Clefs are created or changed by dragging a clef symbol from the clef palette to a measure or another clef.
<F9> toggles the palettes window.
Change
Drag a clef from the palette onto a clef in the score. You can also drag a clef from the score to another clef of the score by using <Shift+leftMouseButton+Drag>.
Add
Drag a clef from the palette onto an empty part of a measure. This creates a clef at the beginning of the measure. If the measure is not the first measure in the staff it is drawn smaller.
Remove
Select a clef and press <Del>.
Note that changing a clef does not change the pitch of any note. Instead the notes are moved.

tr.td: Fingering can be added to notes by dragging a fingering character from the fingering palette to a note head in the score. Fingerings are normal text which can be edited like any other thext.

Frames Frames provide empty space outside of normal measures. They can also contain text or pictures. MuseScore has two kind of frames:
horizontal
Horizontal frames break a System. The width is adjustable and the height equals the system height. HFrames can be used to separate a Coda.
vertical
Vertical frames provide empty space between or before systems. The height is adjustable and the width equals the system width. Vertical frames are used to place titel, subtitle or composer. I you create a titel, a vertical frame is placed before the first measure automatically if its not there already.
Create a frame First select a measure. The command to insert a frame is found at the pulldown menu Create->Measures. The frame is inserted before the selected measure.
Delete a frame Select the frame and press <Del>.
Edit frame Doubleclick at the frame to enter Editmode. A handle appears which can be used to drag the size of the frame.

Grace notes Appoggiatura Acciaccatura
A short grace note (Acciaccatura) is painted as a small note with a stroke through the stem. Its placed before the normal sized main note. A long grace note (Appoggiatura) has no stroke.
Create a grace note by dragging a grace note symbol from the notes palette to a main note.
See also Grace note in Wikipedia.

tr.td:
Keys are created or changed by dragging a key symbol from the key palette to a measure or another key.
<F9> toggles the palettes window.
Change
Drag a key from the palette onto a key in the score. You can also drag a key from the score to another key of the score by using <Shift+leftMouseButton+Drag>.
Add
Drag a key from the palette onto an empty part of a measure. This creates a key at the beginning of the measure.
Remove
Select a key and press <Del>.

museScoreManual.page:
Lyrics
First enter notes.
Select first note.
Type <Ctrl+L> and enter lyrics text for first note.
Type <space> at end of word to go next note.
Type <-> at end of syllable to go to next note. The syllables are connected with a dash.
<Shift+Space> moves to the previous note.
<Ctrl+Space> enters a <space> into the lyrics text.
<Ctrl+Minus> enters a <-> into the lyrics text.
Lyrics can be edited as normal text.
See also Text Chordnames.

Measure Operations Insert Measure Delete Measure
Insert Measures
First select a measure then press Ins to insert a new empty measure before the selected on.
Delete Measures
Complete measures can be deletet by first selecting them with Ctrl+Click. The measure is marked with a dottet line indicating that you selected a "piece of time". Press Shift+Click to extent the selection. Pressing Del removes the selected measures.
Properties
Measure Duration
Normally the nominal and actual duration of a measure is identical. An upbeat can have a different actual duration.
Irregular
An "irregular" measure will not be counted. Normally an upbeat is not counted as a regular measure.
Repeat Count
If the measure is the end of a repeat you can define how often the repeat should be played.

Create new Score
Create new Score from Scratch The menu entry <Score/New> create an empty new score. First you have to populate the empty sheet with instruments and then you can add empty measures.
<I> popups the instrument menu
<Ctrl+B> appends an empty measure
then menu <Create/Measures> can be used to create an arbitrary number of empty measures
Next steps are usually: set clef, set key, set time signature
Create new Score from Template
<N> popups the <Template> menu. Select a template and click <Ok>. This is the simplest way to create a new score. Note that template files are normal MuseScore files stored in the template folder.
Create new Score with the New Wizard

Notes are entered in <Note Edit> mode. First select a note or rest as start position for note entry. When entering notes you are always replacing existing notes or rests. So the duration of a measure does not change.

<Alt+5>1/64 note <Alt+6>1/1 note

Palettes Your can drag&drop palette symbols onto score elements.
A doubleclick on a symbol in a palette is equivalent to drag&drop this symbol to all selected score elements. For example you can easily put a tenuto to several notes at once:
select notes
double click on the tenuto symbol in the attributes palette

Play Mode MuseScore has an integrated sequencer and synthesizer to play your score.
By pressing the <Play> button you enter <Play> mode. In <Play> mode the following commands are available:
<Space>toggle stop/play
<Left> seek to previous chord
<Right> seek to next chord
<Ctrl+Left> seek to previous measure
<Ctrl+Right> seek to next measure
<Home>rewind start of score
<F11>toggle show play panel
If you want to play other instruments than piano you have to change the MuseScore integrated SoundFont with a more capable one in the Preferences menu.

Repeats Start and end of simple repeats can be defined by setting appropriate bar lines. In the last measure of a repeat you can set the property "Repeat Count" to define the nunber of played repeats.
See also: Volta

Text Editing Double click on text to enter edit mode:
In text edit mode the following commands are available:
<Ctrl+B> toggles bold face
<Ctrl+I> toggles italic
<Ctrl+U> toggles underline
<Up> start superscript or end subscript if in subscript mode
<Down> start subscript or end superscript if in superscript mode
move cursor: <Home> <End> <Left> <Right>
<Backspace> remove character left from cursor
<Delete> remove character right from cursor
<Return> start new line
<F2> Show text palette. The text palette can be used to enter special characters and symbols.
See also: Chord Names, Lyrics

Tuplets Triplets
To create a triplet first create a note with a duration of the whole triplet. Then select the note and press <Ctrl+3> to change it to a triplet. Similarly a <Ctrl+5> changes to note to a quintuplet.
First select a note:
<Ctrl+3> creates a triplet:
which can be further edited

Undo/Redo MuseScore has unlimited undo/redo functions.
The standard shortcuts are:
<Ctrl+Z>Undo
<Ctrl+Shift+Z>Redo

Volta Volta brackets are used to mark different endings in a repeat:
The brackets can span more than one measure. Double click the volta to enter edit mode and then move the handles with:
<Shift+Right>one measure left
<Shift+Left>one measure right
This commands move the "logical" start or end of the volta which determine the bracketet measures. Other commands in edit mode also move the handles but do not change how the repeat is played.
If you move the handles, a dashed line from the logical position to the actual position is shown
Properties
Repeat List
This list determines in which repeat the volta should be played. If the volta is played in more than one repeat all repeat numbers must be entered separated with a ",".
Text
You can set an arbitrary volta text. Of course the text should correspond with the repeat list.

One-bar rests When an entire measure is devoid of notes, a semibreve (whole) rest is used.
A one-bar rest can be created by marking a measure and pressing Del. All notes and rests on this measure are then replaced by a one-bar rest.

Crescendo Diminuendo Decrescendo Hairpins
Hairpins are line objects.
To create a hairpin first select a note to mark the start point.
H create a crescendo hairpin
Shift+H create a diminuendo hairpin (decrescendo)
Haipins could also be created by dragging a hairpin symbol from the line palette to a note head.
